Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "7th Iberoamerican Congress on Geometry" that will be held on January 22-26, 2018 at the Universidad de Valladolid, in Valladolid, Spain.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis and Geometry, especially in the fields of Riemann surfaces and Teichmuller theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: http://iberoamericangeometry2018.uva.es/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 7th Iberoamerican Congress on Geometry took place in Valladolid, Spain, January 22-26, 2018. This conference attracted about 150 participants coming from all over Europe, North and South America; it featured 9 plenary talks by distinguished speakers from the US, Chile, France, Germany, Mexico, Spain, and 6 parallel sessions with a total of over 50 session talks given. 

The Congress was the seventh installment of the roughly triennial series that brings together mathematicians working on areas in geometry. broadly in areas where Riemann surfaces play role, following in the tradition of Ahlfors and Bers. Historically most participants of the congresses were from the US, Chile, Mexico, and Spain. This time, with a conference in Spain, the congress also attracted some researchers from France and Germany, as well as from Japan and Korea. 

One of the main goals of the Iberoamerican Congresses on Geometry is to bring together various communities of researchers working in related but distinct areas, and to foster interactions and exchange of the ideas. Thus most participants attended all of the plenary talks, and thus heard about the research results and questions in realted areas. Many of them were motivated to further learn about these by attending section talks and in conversations with other experts. 

The NSF support via the conference grant enabled participation of mathematicians from the US, especially of graduate students, postdocs, and speakers without other sources of outside funding. The grant partially supported the conference attendance expenses of 21 participants from the US, including 10 graduate students from the US universities, 8 female participants from the US, and 11 speakers, special session organizers, and poster presenters (these are overlapping categories).

The entire conference schedule is available at
http://iberoamericangeometry2018.uva.es/ 

while the videos of all plenary talks are available at
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSbo9kXA_LcwKQC519l5kUhpEf8ENNKh5

The congress was successful in surveying the state of the field and allowing researchers from different fields and different countries to learn from each other and forge new collaborations. The NSF grant allowed the US mathematicians to benefit from this
